case_name: State of Bombay v. Respondents (Civil Appeals Nos. 145, 146 and 147 of 1952)

facts.text: This judgment governs Civil Appeals Nos. 146 and 147 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Bose, J. This judgment will govern Civil Appeals Nos. 146 and 147 of 1952 as well. We will first deal with the questions that are companymon to them all.

facts.text: Three petitions made in the Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: They arise out of three petitions made in the Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under article 266 of the Constitution. The writs have been granted

facts.text: Writs of mandamus granted by Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals. The facts are these.

facts.text: State of Bombay appeals against grant of writs.

anchor.surface_text: The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals. The facts are these. The Governor of Bombay

facts.text: Governor of Bombay issued orders through Assistant Controller of Accommodation under section 6(4)(a) of Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Governor of Bombay, acting through the Assistant Controller of Accommodation, issued orders under section 6 4  a  of the Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948, in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952

facts.text: Governor of Bombay issued order under section 5(1) in Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952 requisitioning premises of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: and under section 5 1  in Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952, requisitioning the premises of the three respondents. The question is whether these orders are ultra vires.

facts.text: Premises of the three respondents requisitioned.

anchor.surface_text: requisitioning the premises of the three respondents. The question is whether these orders are ultra vires.

facts.text: Respondents are either owners or tenants of the requisitioned premises.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are either the owners or the tenants of the premises requisitioned. In Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1952 the respondents are uncle and nephew.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1952, first respondent is uncle and tenant, second respondent is nephew living with family in premises.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1952 the respondents are uncle and nephew. The uncle, who is the first respondent, is the tenant. The second respondent in his nephew. He and his family live with the first respondent

facts.text: Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 would have expired in April 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1948 would have expired in April, 1950, but its life was extended by Bombay Act II of 1950.

facts.text: Life of Act extended by Bombay Act II of 1950.

facts.text: Housing situation in Bombay acute due to influx of refugees.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the housing situation in Bombay was acute, largely due to the influx of refugees. Questions of public decency, public morals, public health

facts.text: Learned Attorney-General gave assurance that possession of petitioners will not be disturbed.

anchor.surface_text: because of the assurance given by the learned Attorney-General that the possession of the petitioners in this case will number be disturbed for any reason

facts.text: Government of Bombay passed Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance in 1947 and invited applications for allotment of vacancies.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1947 the Government of Bombay passed the Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance and invited applications for the allotment of vacancies from the general public.

facts.text: In 1949 and 1950, Government declared it would not consider further applications from public, restrict to Government and public purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in 1949, and again in 1950, Government declared that it would number companysider further applications from the public as it had decided to restrict

facts.text: Allottees in present appeals are first informants of suppressed vacancies who needed accommodation.

anchor.surface_text: The allottees in the present appeals are from that class. Despite this it was found that the number of applications so far exceeded the number of vacancies

facts.text: Court holds requisition orders valid for public purpose of housing homeless.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that neither the order of requisition number the order of allotment in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 is ultra vires.

issues.text: whether these orders are ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether these orders are ultra vires. They are attacked on a number of grounds the first of which goes to the root of the matter.

issues.text: whether these two sections are ultra vires articles 19(1)(f) and 31(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: these two sections are ultra vires articles 19 1 f and 31 2 of the Constitution. The respondents are either the owners or the tenants of the premises requisitioned.

issues.text: whether article 19(1)(f) applies to tenants and licensees in cases of requisition involving substantial deprivation of property

anchor.surface_text: when there is a substantially total deprivation of property which is already held and enjoyed, one must turn to article 31 to see how far that is justified.

issues.text: whether the requisition was for a public purpose

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for compensation in section 8, so all we have to see is whether the requisition was for a public purpose. The main Act is pre-Constitution

issues.text: whether they were made for a State or public purpose as set out in sections 5(1) and 6(4)

anchor.surface_text: The first question, therefore, is, whether they were made for a State or public purpose as set out in sections 5 1 and 6 4 ? Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 have similar orders.

arguments.claim: requisition and allotment orders not ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: We hold that neither the order of requisition nor the order of allotment in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 is ultra vires.

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) does not apply to tenants and licensees where requisition results in substantially total deprivation of property already held and enjoyed; such cases are governed by Article 31.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, article 19 1  f  does number apply to them. In The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose  1954 S.C.R. 587 , and Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others  1954 S.C.R. 674 , the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1  f  and 31 deal with different subjects and companyer different fields.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedents (Subodh Gopal Bose, Dwarkadas Shrinivas, Gopalan) distinguishing fields of Art.19(1)(f) (restrictions on existing property rights) and Art.31 (deprivation); substantial deprivation robs attributes of ownership/tenancy like occupation and transfer.

holdings.text: Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 (as amended) is not invalid under Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(2) for lack of public purpose requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Following that decision we hold that the Act is number invalid for this reason. We number turn to the orders of requisition. They can only be upheld if they companyform to the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public purpose implied from preamble, tenor of ss.5-6, and intendment of Act per precedent (Kameshwar Singh); compensation provided in s.8 satisfies Art.31.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to set out the public purpose in the requisition order itself.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is number necessary to set out the purpose of the requisition in the order. The desirability of such a companyrse is obvious because when it is number done proof of the purpose must be given in other ways

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirable but not mandatory if purpose proved otherwise (affidavits, context); applies principle from Biswabhusan Naik v. State of Orissa.

holdings.text: Requisition orders made for public purpose of providing housing accommodation to homeless persons.

anchor.surface_text: In the present set of cases there is proof of a public purpose. It is given in the affidavits made on behalf of the State and in the subsequent orders just quoted, namely to house the homeless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proved by affidavits, subsequent orders, housing crisis due to refugees; fulfills State/public purpose under ss.5(1),6(4)(a); policy rewards first informants of vacancies aids detection and equitable distribution.

holdings.text: Government has wide discretion in allotting requisitioned premises to homeless persons, including first informants of suppressed vacancies, provided done reasonably without fraud etc.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this is number a proper approach to the problem. The Constitution authorises requisitions for a public purpose. The purpose here is finding accommodation for the homeless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad policy discretion necessary given scarcity; courts defer if reasonable principles followed (urgency, efficiency, equity helps vigilant); no fraud alleged.

holdings.text: Burden of proof lies on petitioners challenging validity of requisition order to show it is illegal, as order is prima facie valid and they have special knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the burden was wrongly placed. The petitioners came to Court with the allegation that Government had passed an illegal order against them. On the face of it, the order is number illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challengers bear onus against presumptively lawful executive order; petitioners have special knowledge of facts like letting/intent under s.4(3).

holdings.text: Neither requisition nor allotment orders in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 are ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that neither the order of requisition number the order of allotment in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 is ultra vires. In Civil Appeal No. 146 of 1952 a further question arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comply with ss.5(1),6(4)(a) public purpose, s.4(3); constitutional under Art.31; purpose proved, no need to specify in order.

holdings.text: Requisition order in Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952 valid for public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, we held that there was a public purpose and that the orders here were valid. The only other question, namely, whether a mandamus can issue number, becomes unnecessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same reasons as above apply to s.5(1) order.

Others  1954 S.C.R. 674 , the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1  f  and 31 deal with different subjects and companyer different fields.

Others  1954 S.C.R. 674 , the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1  f  and 31 deal with different subjects and companyer different fields. There was some disagreement about the nature and scope of the difference but all were agreed that there was numberoverlapping.

precedents.cited_proposition: articles 19(1)(f) and 31 deal with different subjects and cover different fields

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras  1950 S.C.R. 88

anchor.surface_text: A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras  1950 S.C.R. 88 , where it was held that the freedoms relating to the person of a citizen guaranteed by article 19 assume the existence of a free citizen and can numberlonger be enjoyed if a citizen is deprived of his liberty by the law of preventive or punitive detention.

precedents.case_name: A K Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: freedoms under article 19 assume existence of free citizen and cannot be enjoyed if deprived of liberty

anchor.surface_text: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others 1954 S.C.R. 674 . These articles deal with substantial and substantive rights and number with illusory phantoms of title. When every form of enjoyment which numbermally accompanies an interest in this king of property is taken away leaving the mere husk of title,

precedents.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: article 19(1)(f) deals with substantial deprivation, not illusory rights

precedents.citation: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others 1954 S.C.R. 674 , at page 734

anchor.surface_text: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others 1954 S.C.R. 674 , at page 734 - By substantial deprivation is meant the sort of deprivation that substantially robs a man of those attributes of enjoyment which numbermally accompany rights to, or an interest in, property.

precedents.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: substantial deprivation robs attributes of enjoyment normally accompanying property rights; substance over form
precedents.cited_holding: By substantial deprivation is meant the sort of deprivation that substantially robs a man of those attributes of enjoyment which normally accompany rights to, or an interest in, property. The form is unessential. It is the substance that one must seek.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1952 S.C.R. 889, 940

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1952 S.C.R. 889, 940  that - It is unnecessary to state in express terms in the statute itself the precise purpose for which property is being taken, provided from the whole tenor and intendment of the Act it companyld be gathered that the property was being acquired either for purposes of the State or for purposes of the public and that the intention was to benefit the companymunity at large.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: unnecessary to expressly state public purpose in statute if gathered from tenor of Act
precedents.cited_holding: It is unnecessary to state in express terms in the statute itself the precise purpose for which property is being taken, provided from the whole tenor and intendment of the Act it could be gathered that the property was being acquired either for purposes of the State or for purposes of the public and that the intention was to benefit the community at large.

precedents.citation: Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa applies here. In the present set of cases there is proof of a public purpose. It is given in the affidavits made on behalf of the State and in the subsequent orders just quoted, namely to house the homeless.

precedents.case_name: Biswabhusan Naik v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: omission to set out purpose in order not fatal if purpose proved otherwise
